title: Font with the most attractive "K" and "k"?
content:
I’ve a friend who’s first initial is “K.” She is disturbed by the dearth of attractively formed instances of that poor, put-upon character, the “K.” In an effort to cheer her I listed several faces I find attractive, from Bembo to Garamond and even Caslon. She dismissed each saying, in effect, that the “K” and the “k” were ugly, pathetic things. And so, dear friends, I turn to you. Help me find this lady the letter of her dreams, an attractive “Kk” in an attractive font.

comments.content:
Five favorites:

[Bell](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=M.515.0.1&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=Katy+kisses&sampleSize=48&attributes.paraSize=14&paraSize=14)  
 [Walbaum](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/walbaum-text/regular/testdrive.html?s=Katy+kisses&p=48)  
 [Tarzana Narrow](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=E.103796.0.1&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=Katy+kisses&sampleSize=48&attributes.paraSize=14&paraSize=14)  
 [Reykjavik Two](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_reykjavik2.html)  
 [Table Manners](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.psyops.com/html/spec_tabman.html)

You’ll have to play with the last two by clicking the screentest feature at the top of the screen.
Lowercase k is one of my favorite letters

I am sensitive to this letter as well. [Ambroise](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/Ambroise/?SID=7c76c6c6f91870ee118197ef8a48d857) — any part of the family — but I am partial to the black weights.

Speak Up has a [new entry critiquing the alphabet](http://web.archive.org/web/20080614062159/http:/www.underconsideration.com/speakup/archives/002383.html#002383)j. Check out the comments on Kk, they get big props!
Figures I would make a typo in “alphabet.” Sigh.
